title: 110_hr4218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with millions affected and increasing prevalence. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to effectively manage their condition, provided by certified educators. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified educators, has been proven effective in reducing risks and complications. Lifestyle changes can significantly decrease the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, especially in older individuals. Certified diabetes educators play a crucial role in helping patients control their diabetes and improve their health. Lifestyle changes taught by these educators lead to better glycemic control and reduced complications. Proper medical treatment and self-management can prevent serious complications of diabetes by up to 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke. There are over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US, most of whom are certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certified diabetes educators, licensed by a State as health professionals, are uniquely qualified to provide diabetes self-management training under the Medicare program. They must meet specific professional credentials, have years of experience in diabetes self-management training, pass a national examination, and renew their credentials periodically. Certified diabetes educators are recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are licensed health care professionals specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. A recognized certifying body for diabetes educators, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, must meet specific requirements set by the Secretary, including being incorporated and registered in the United States and requiring a qualifying credential in a specified healthcare profession for certification. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services, including economic and geographic obstacles, availability of referrals, and qualified providers. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods to educate primary care physicians and the public about diabetes self-management training. A report on the recommendations will be submitted to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will submit a report to Congress on recommendations for diabetes self-management training. The amendments will apply to services provided six months after the Act's enactment.
